> Do we consider to do physical index based query later?

Yes I'll do that later

There was a long discussion one year ago, this search is simple but has a super bad performance impact on the trace query. So, the community has decided to remove it.
This is a community, diverse groups of people, make the final decision. If you want your voice to be considered seriously, you need to be a part of the committer team based on your contributions to this community. 
A project can't make everyone happy
please， How to be part of the submitter team.
I hope to submit the corresponding code to contribute to this community

There is no `submitter team` in the ASF.
The committer team is the one is trusted by the PMC(Project Management Committee), who could do routine code review and merging. The PMC is a smaller group of people watching and sheepherders of the project. 

This doc would show how a committer gets promoted, https://skywalking.apache.org/docs/main/latest/en/guides/asf/committer/, and here are the current committers and PMC members, https://skywalking.apache.org/team/.

The basic principle is, that you need to begin contributing to the project through pull requests, such as bug fixing, or begin to work on a new feature if you have an idea, the idea gets discussed, and at least one of PMC gets you to support to do.

SkyWalking is a community of volunteers, so, there is no one to assign you anything, you need to find things to do because you feel you want to.

About this feature(endpoint name-based search), the conclusion was made, that unless we have committers to initial a new discussion again, we wouldn't accept it back in the mainstream. This is how a community works, we have 600+ code contributors, and countless users. The decision is the decision, very serious, not be able to change randomly.

sorry , problem is not exist.
After I checked backend-sample carefully.
I found that the sample algorithms use traceId hash as sample factor.
And that can guarantee the trace tree not break。

related code:
org.apache.skywalking.oap.server.analyzer.provider.trace.parser.listener.TraceSegmentSampler#shouldSample

```
public boolean shouldSample(String traceId) {
 return Math.abs(traceId.hashCode()) % 10000 < traceSampleRateWatcher.getSampleRate();
}
```

This problem is because the files in proto in the network module of skywalking project are stored separately in another project. It is not allowed to clone or download the source code of skywalking alone. You need to clone the corresponding Apache/skywalking data collect protocol project or download it to skywalking/apm-protocol/apm-network/src/main/proto directory

https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/25ebd6c242d776c06bd5b912e82f31d21892c2f4/oap-server/server-storage-plugin/storage-banyandb-plugin/src/main/java/org/apache/skywalking/oap/server/storage/plugin/banyandb/BanyanDBAggregationQueryDAO.java#L51-L99

This is how we apply query from OAP side.
I am feeling a little curious about what are storage-e2e testing more now?
The storage E2E tests entity, entity relation, trace, and event between all storage. It seems that only storage E2E tests are verifying these across storage, except for events.

Hi @Superskyyy 
I'm trying to run a Django application with gunicorn. It is unable to start the agent. I followed this thread and https://opentelemetry-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/fork-process-model/README.html

Here is my wsgi.py

```
import os

from django.core.wsgi import get_wsgi_application


from uwsgidecorators import postfork
from skywalking import agent, config

def post_fork(server, worker):
    print("abc")
    config.init(collector_address='xxxxx', service_name='test-1')
    agent.start()

os.environ.setdefault("DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE", "myproject.settings")

application = get_wsgi_application()


```
this is the command to start the application
**gunicorn myproject.wsgi --workers 2**

Any suggestions.

I use docker to deploy version 9.0 and the same problem occurs.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6300036/170230848-72c30f38-26ca-4010-a73a-d3d7cc5a436b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6300036/170230914-da869abd-7926-4914-8548-79c5bca269df.png)
@qyddle Your backend is not working.
We should add `on-demand logs` here. And one question, on which dashboards we are going to add this feature? `Service Mesh` and `Kubernetes`?

> > > We should add `on-demand logs` here. > > And one question, on which dashboards we are going to add this feature? `Service Mesh` and `Kubernetes`? I discussed with @Fine0830 and want to put it here
This is good, recommend considering putting into k8s dashboard as well.

> 
@pacific28 I think your issue originates from that you haven't registered the `post_fork` hook in the gunicorn startup command.

try something like this `gunicorn -c path_to_your_hook_config myproject.wsgi --workers 2` Take a look here for an complete example https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/blob/master/examples/example_config.py

Actually we have our own docs for using with post-fork servers now, feel free to enhance it as it didn't explicitly mention gunicorn.

https://skywalking.apache.org/docs/skywalking-python/latest/en/setup/faq/how-to-use-with-uwsgi/

@YueLangsugar Thanks for reporting the potential problem, you checked the `Yes I am willing to submit a PR!` button, are you currently investigating a fix? It's not necessarily called a bug as there's no problem with the agent code, it's related to how Python works.

This is the same problem that many issues have mentioned, pre-fork server models do not work out-of-box with spawned threads in Python, that is - you used `http_server.start(2)`. Here you have two identical processes handling the traffic where only one agent is attached to the original process. 

You need to pass a post_fork hook definition to the server, and pass to the server config/ startup command
```
# This is pseudo code
def post_fork():
	agent.start()
	blabla
```
as we discussed in many places. (no one mentioned explicitly Tornado yet, so you could help to enhance the documentation FAQ to mention how to configure the hook for Tornado, I'm not sure if there's a way for its built-in server? It's a good idea to investigate this - for built-in Tornado HTTP server)
https://skywalking.apache.org/docs/skywalking-python/latest/en/setup/faq/how-to-use-with-uwsgi/
https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/9071 > on enhancing this experience and make it fully automatic for users.
https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/8566#issuecomment-1137451755

Please also reformat your issue properly using ```. It's currently hard to read.

I am afraid this is not what Satellite is designed for. Satellite is mostly for gRPC based channels, and as Nginx/APISIX/Kong only support HTTP1 to report data, you should make it to OAP directly. Or, you could put another HTTP proxy(Nginx/Envoy etc.) to provide load balance.

You should submit this to discussion because this is not a bug.

@wu-sheng  If other agents do not enhance the class during the first load (transform), the class will be enhanced during the second transform. Then skywalking directly returns the byte stream cached for the first time in the second time, will it overwrite the content enhanced for the second time by other agents? Because the order in which the transform is executed depends on the order in which the Agent is configured.

@wu-sheng  If other agent do not enhance the class during the first load (transform), the class will be enhanced during the second transform. Then skywalking directly returns the byte stream cached for the first time in the second time, will it overwrite the content enhanced for the second time by other agents? Because the order in which the transform is executed depends on the order in which the Agent is configured.
Thanks for fixing it. It is interesting to see netty fails on specific OS.

I just tried and didn't meet the same problem on a Windows machine. From the PyPI site, I think there are extra system-level dependencies before it can be properly installed on Linux. 

I don't think any popular tool (pip, poetry etc.) will be able to handle system-level dependencies at this stage as there's ongoing academic research for it. So we are gonna have to fix it ourselves.
```
Linux
Note that this is a basic step. I can not support complete step for build for all environment. If you can see some error, you should fix it by yourself, or ask for support in some user forum. Don't file a issue on the issue tracker.

You may need to install the Python 3 and MySQL development headers and libraries like so:

$ sudo apt-get install python3-dev default-libmysqlclient-dev build-essential # Debian / Ubuntu
% sudo yum install python3-devel mysql-devel # Red Hat / CentOS
Then you can install mysqlclient via pip now:
```

```
sudo apt-get install python3-dev default-libmysqlclient-dev build-essential
```

That did it thx. I had python3-dev installed but not the mysql stuff.

I think generally, we should not report errors if this instance doesn't have on-demand logs. 

If you want this available on the UI, we could add one more field for the response.
> If you want this available on the UI, we could add one more field for the response. Why? UI already displays the errors reported by backend correctly,

This kind of exception would make us suffer many questions from new users since the day we release this, from my experience. Many of them are throwing any exception to this issue channel without thinking or reading.

`The on-demand log is not available for this instance.` may be a better statement on the on-demand widget.

Notice, please fix `https://skywalking.apache.org/docs/main/latest/en/setup/backend/on-demand-pod-log/`'s menu, there is a extra `g` in the menu link.

Also, could you reword this doc to follow the latest changes? Please highlight those two key properties, and which values should be put.

Thanks for this proposal. There are some tips for you.

The CRD should contain the following configuration:
1. The [sidecar configuration](https://github.com/apache/skywalking-swck/blob/master/docs/java-agent-injector.md#configure-sidecar). As you said, the user can create a `sidecar template` to upgrade the agent.
2. The [annotation configuration](https://github.com/apache/skywalking-swck/blob/master/docs/java-agent-injector.md#use-annotations-to-overlay-default-agent-configuration).  Users can create an `annotation template`.
3. The [labelselector](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/labels/) to define which target object should be updated, like deployment/statefulset etc.

The Controller should do the following things:
1. When the user creates/updates a CR, the controller can get the target object with the labelselector of the CR and inject the annotation to the target object.
